work.p: This manuscript is a draft of lines that first appeared in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, in a poem that was originally untitled and that would eventually be entitled "Who Learns My Lesson Complete?": "I know it is wonderful . . . . but my eyesight is equally wonderful . . . . and how I was conceived in my mother's womb is equally wonderful, / And how I was not palpable once but am now . . . . and was born on the last day of May 1819 . . . . and passed from a babe in the creeping trance of three summers and three winters to articulate and walk . . . . are all equally wonderful" (1855, p. 92).

titleStmt.title: born at all is equally
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: A poetic fragment which was used slightly revised in "Who Learns My Lesson Complete?," a poem that was untitled when it first appeared as part of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. Revised versions of this poem appeared throughout the editions of Leaves of Grass, the final title first appearing in 1871–1872.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: born at all is equally wonderful
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: A list of words is written on the back of this manuscript leaf.
Transcribed from digital images of the original.

body.l:
born at all is equally wonderful . . . .
and that I rose from passed from being
a babe in the infantile creeping trance of
three years summers and three winters to be articulate child
